newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft CFO sees $10 billion revs in FY.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft CFO sees $10 billion revs in FY.

text.p: Microsoft Corp chief financial officer Mike Brown said he thought the company could top $10 billion in revenues for the current fiscal year ending in June 1997.
"I think we can get there this year," he said in a conference call with analysts monitored by Reuters.
The computer software giant posted revenues of about $2.30 billion in the fiscal first quarter that ended September 30.

Brown said he expected the company to post a sequential increase similar to the $121 million rise in last year's fiscal second quarter, despite more difficult comparisons this year because of last year's introduction of the Windows 95 operating system.
Brown also estimated Microsoft would defer about 30 percent of its Office 97 upgrade revenues over the first 12 months of availability.
He said the upgrade, which he called "very important", would become available late in the current quarter, with no significant revenues until the March quarter.

Microsoft defers revenues from cyclical products such as Office and its Windows operating systems to account for costs incurred after the sale, such as technical support and components delivered later.

Microsoft also defers revenues from sales through its software licensing and maintenance programmes. Brown said Microsoft planned to launch a new licensing programme next year that would "strengthen our long-term franchise at the expense of near-term reported revenues".
